description: From Middle English horner, hornere, equivalent to horn +â€Ž -er.

entries.meaning: Someone who works or deals in (animal) horn or horns.
examples: As also all patents for new inventions not put in practice within three years, likewise the several grants of incorporation to hatband makers, gutstring makers, spectacle makers, comb makers, tobacco-pipe makers, butchers, and horners.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Someone who blows a horn (the musical insturment); a hornblower.
The British sand lance or sand eel, Hyperoplus lanceolatus.
